--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> I guess I'll throw my 2 cents into this discussion. 
> As Mitchell
> pointed out, no one is really right or wrong when it
> comes to definitions.  

I at least agree with that.  And especially complex or
difficult processes are that much more difficult to
define.

It seems to me, though, that AI researchers who are
borrowing conceptually from across disciplines may
find it less confusing and more beneficial to try to
remain more consistent with the concepts from those
older, more mature fields.

And from everything I've read in evolutionary biology
or population genetics, the overriding
conceptualization of evolution as a process of
heritable change over time, with that change being
brought about by several forces, only one of which is
natural selection.

> Nevertheless, I prefer to use
> terminology in a way that
> is intuitive and simple, and I feel that Derek's
> definition of
> evolution, though arguably technically sound, does
> not fit my
> intuitions and is therefore potentially misleading. 
> (Misleading
> because only someone who knew Derek and his
> reasoning would be able to
> appreciate his assumptions.)  

Well they aren't just my assumptions.  By the way, are
there any life sciences majors or degree holders
lurking around here?

> The problem I have is
> that evolution to
> me includes the central notion of "survival of the
> fittest," and
> Derek's "evolution with pure drift" has no notion of
> fitness at all,
> making it quite in contrast to my intuitions.  

Again, it's not just my notion.  It's an inherent
concept in evolutionary biology.

From the University of Arizona web page:

http://www.biology.arizona.edu/evolution/act/drift/drift.html

"The three major forces of evolution are mutation,
selection, and random genetic drift. These forces
cause changes in genotypes and phenotypes over time,
and also determine the amount and kind of variation
seen in a population."

From an NYU profs site:

http://www.nyu.edu/projects/fitch/courses/evolution/html/genetic_drift.html#GeneticDrift

"I.  Genetic drift:  the effect of population size
alone on allele and genotype frequencies

A.  Finite population size alone results in a change
in allele frequency (which results in a decline in
heterozygosity)

<snip>

II.  Genetic drift can result in evolutionary
divergence

1.  Because of genetic drift, the variance between
demes (small subpopulations) increases over time
(i.e., demes will diverge, esp. if they become
isolated)."


And genetic drift plays a huge role in biological
speciation.  Small groups of individuals may diverge
evolutionarily for reasons that have *nothing* to do
with their fitness.

Here's a good article from ScienceDaily Magazine that
explains the impact of genetic drift on evolution:

http://www.sciencedaily.com/encyclopedia/Genetic_drift

"Genetic drift is a mechanism of evolution that acts
in concert with natural selection to change species
characteristics over time. Like selection, it acts on
populations, altering which traits and which alleles
predominate among members and changing the diversity
of the group. Unlike selection, however, drift occurs
only in small populations and results in changes that
need not be adaptive. A statistical effect, it arises
from the role of chance in the production of
offspring."

So I'm not the only one arguing that genetic drift (or
the sampling effect, or whatever you'd like to call
it) may have a profound effect on the evolution of a
population, especially if that population is
relatively small (like many used in GAs).  

To view evolution as *only* a result of natural
selection is misleading, I believe.  Especially in our
case, when we're trying to emulate evolution and
harness it to solve particular
problems...understanding the pressures at work that
affect the dynamics of the evolving population are
crucial.  Especially when it comes to trying to
determine optimal parameters such as population sizes
and survival rates.  

Smaller populations and smaller survival (or
selection, or sampling) rates are going to increase
the effect of genetic drift, are they not?

Derek
